bibl.title: Notes for remarks upon the acceptance of The Order of Finlay, by [Philip Showalter Hench], [1952]

div1.p: [Hench] outlines remarks to be made upon his acceptance of “The Order of Finlay.” He speaks highly of Finlay and states that one of his most valued possessions is an original copy of Finlay's first paper on yellow fever and mosquitoes.

div1.head: Notes for remarks upon the acceptance of The Order of Finlay, by [Philip Showalter Hench], [1952]
div1.p:
Dr. Andreu: Among my most valued medical
possessions is an original copy (Havana
1881) of Dr. Finlay's first paper on yell
ow fever and mosquitos. On more than one
occasion I have read every word of the
official translation of that paper. My
familiarity with this work and my love
of medical history requires me to say
that the conception of Carlos Finlay was
one of the boldest, most original and pre-
cise in the long history of medicine. ¶So
profound and mysterious was the secret of
nature which he first tried to uncover
that it took many years before his brilli
ant theory was proven and accepted. That
is one measure of the difficulties involv
ed. ¶But now he is honored by the whole won
world because he was a true servant of all
people. His work and his memory deserve
the highest awards of science and the last
ing gratitude of mankind. ¶It is a unique
pleasure for me to receive this distinction
which carries his illustrious name, a fra-
ternal honor which I am happy to accept
as a representative of the American medica
profession and of the Mayo Clinic.

To you, sir, and to the Cuban people my
most sincere thanks.
